title: Practice std::cout and std::cin
description:
Write a program that prompts for a first name and age, reads both values, and prints a personalised summary.

Steps:
1. Print the prompt `Enter your first name:` and read a single-word name using `std::cin`.
2. Print the prompt `Enter your age:` and read an integer age using `std::cin`.
3. Output `Hello, {name}! You are {age} years old.` exactly, replacing `{name}` and `{age}` with the captured values.
4. Output `Ready to explore iostream!` as the final line (end the line with either `std::endl` or `\n`).

Input format:
- Line 1: first name (single word).
- Line 2: age (integer).

Expected output (exactly four lines):
Enter your first name:
Enter your age:
Hello, {name}! You are {age} years old.
Ready to explore iostream!

Example run (input `Ada` then `21`):
Enter your first name:
Enter your age:
Hello, Ada! You are 21 years old.
Ready to explore iostream!

tests.name: formats Ada correctly
tests.expected:
Enter your first name:
Enter your age:
Hello, Ada! You are 21 years old.
Ready to explore iostream!

tests.name: formats Jānis correctly
tests.expected:
Enter your first name:
Enter your age:
Hello, Janis! You are 19 years old.
Ready to explore iostream!

hints: Use std::cin >> name; to read a single word from standard input.
Match the punctuation exactly: comma, exclamation mark, and period all matter.
Send the final line through std::cout << ... << std::endl; if you want to flush immediately.
